alert.note: Alert for Central Interior; Deltana and Tanana Flats; Denali; Eastern Alaska Range; Middle Tanana Valley; Southeastern Brooks Range; Upper Koyukuk Valley; Upper Tanana Valley and the Fortymile Country; Yukon Flats and Surrounding Uplands (Alaska) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Special Weather Statement issued July 22 at 3:25PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks
info.description: ...Very Hot Over The Eastern Interior Through Monday... ...High Water On The Tanana River Into Next Week... The Eastern Interior will become very hot this weekend with isolated afternoon thunderstorms. Temperatures are in the 80s over most of the Eastern Interior today, and will rise into the 80s and low 90s on Sunday and Monday. Fairbanks is expected to reach 90 on Sunday and Monday. Similar hot conditions with isolated afternoon thunderstorms will likely continue over the Eastern Interior into the middle of next week. People should take precautions against heat this weekend. The Tanana River is near bankfull, and will remain very high through next week. This high water is due to rising freezing levels adding high elevation snow and glacial melt this weekend into next week. Other glacial rivers draining the Alaska Range such as the Delta and Nenana Rivers will also remain very high into next week. Most gravel bars on the Tanana River will be covered by water, and some normally dry sloughs and other low lying areas will fill with water. These glacial rivers will contain an increased numbers of logs and trees floating down them through next week and boaters should use caution. The sustained high water could cause erosion problems along the Tanana, Delta and Nenena Rivers through next week. Thunderstorms today and Sunday could contain hail and winds gusting to 30 mph. Strong thunderstorms with heavy rainfall are possible Monday and Tuesday which could cause flash flooding in steep terrain of the Alaska and Brooks Ranges, and flooding if they occur over the already bankfull glacial rivers in the Tanana Valley.
